publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 90.8

seg.seg: (The king says to himself:) ... (you were held) back; by separation from [your] loved ones you were tormented in this common saṃsāra. ....
... With the bonds of ... you were bound through long ages. Now give up this lotus(-like) (?) [son] ... ! ...
.... having (s)eized (the son), he sets him upon his knees [and] began (to) kiss [his] little face with [his] tongue. ...
... (den Prinzen Uttara) ergriffen habend, setzt er [scil. König Araṇemi] ihn auf [seine] Knie [und] begann, sein Gesichtchen mit der Zunge zu küssen.
... having grasped (prince Uttara), he [i.e. king Araṇemi] put him onto [his] knee [and] began, to kiss his little face with [his] tongue.
... “You, my life-bearing dear son! This one there is [your] second dear father, [a dear father] without ill will. Now (your first father) leaves you.” ...
... (The prince Uttara spe)aks: “Father, do you intend to give me away?” The king speaks: “My darling! To the Brahmins I give you as a gift!” ....
.... (The prince Uttara) speaks: “My dear lord father! (Yakṣa)s those are, [they are] not Brahmins! They will surely eat me up! To these evil ....

p.note: The translation follows 312. In 21 the first two lines are interpreted as a soliloquy by the king, as a “Zwiegespräch mit dem eigenen Ich” (i.e. “dialogue with the inner self”; 185).
Fragment of one side of a leaf, probably the verso of the leaf directly following , so originally leaf 17 of the manuscript.

Sieg/Siegling propose to read and restore kä(r)py(eṃ) "common", cf. kärpye-saṃsār in b 4; but there is a trace of the vowel sign left that can only be ā, o, or au, cf. 312, fn. 56, who, nevertheless, accepts the correction to kä(r)py(eṃ). The middle Pt III form p(·)lyks(·)t(·) has to be restored to a zero-grade form p(a)lyks(a)t(ai); see 111, fn. 6 with ref. At the end, Sieg/Siegling restored (twe no), 50, fn. 7(twe ṣek).

50, fn. 8 also propose the word separation uppāll e, and even though words starting with le are rare (none fits here), such a gemination in sandhi is unusual. Sandhi gemination is usually found at morpheme boundaries, but, to my knowledge, not in compounds (the form may be one).
Note the tense alternation between present and preterite.

There is no trace of an anusvara on either autsate-ne (for auntsate) in line 3 or brāhmaṇets (for brāhmaṇeṃts) in line 5, so that Sieg/Siegling restore one in both cases; however, these are rather instances of genuine nasal loss in front of ts, which is a feauture of late and colloquial texts; see 69.

The reading sauśka for soṃśka is certain; a similar form sauśke is found on the following leaf b 6. Even though the graphemes oṃ and au look quite similar, the two spellings are most likely not simply due to copyist errors but are rather hypercorrect spellings, since in the late/colloquial language the sequence oṃś turns to auś; see 91-93.

At the beginning, 51, fn. 3 propose to restore the m-Part. (miwama)ne "trembling". As for the restoration of the lacuna, Sieg/Siegling in 21, fn. 14 propose the nom.pl. yākṣi (as attested in a 1), reading two completely missing akṣaras. In contrast, 51, fn. 4 restore yakṣī based on a 3/4. Then Thomas in 238 withdraws this interpretation, arguing for yākṣi again. However, there is a trace of the vowel sign left, which can only belong to a long ī, not to a short one.

list.item: 1 (The king says to himself:) ... (you were held) back; by separation from [your] loved ones you were tormented in this common saṃsāra. .... 2 ... With the bonds of ... you were bound through long ages. Now give up this lotus(-like) (?) [son] ... ! ... 3 .... having (s)eized (the son), he sets him upon his knees [and] began (to) kiss [his] little face with [his] tongue. ... 4 ... “You, my life-bearing dear son! This one there is [your] second dear father, [a dear father] without ill will. Now (your first father) leaves you.” ... 5 ... (The prince Uttara spe)aks: “Father, do you intend to give me away?” The king speaks: “My darling! To the Brahmins I give you as a gift!” .... 6 .... (The prince Uttara) speaks: “My dear lord father! (Yakṣa)s those are, [they are] not Brahmins! They will surely eat me up! To these evil ....
Fragment of one side of a leaf, probably the verso of the leaf directly following [[THT 82]], so originally leaf 17 of the manuscript.

Alternative classifications:
Peyrot–
Malzahn–
TamaiII-3 (800-900)
Tamai-C14–

3 ... (den Prinzen Uttara) ergriffen habend, setzt er [scil. König Araṇemi] ihn auf [seine] Knie [und] begann, sein Gesichtchen mit der Zunge zu küssen. 369

1 # %14 /// n(·) aṣkār|aṣkāro : #Xx lareṃnmeṃ tsrelñ(e)s(a) ; saṃsārn(e) kärpiyeṃ|kä(r)py{e}ṃ ce ; p(a)lyks(a)t(ai twe no) #Xx /// 2 %3 /// (śa)nmausa ; śānmyatai prākre twe ; pärkareṃ|pärkreṃ prekentsa : #Xx ñake nai printsar ce ; uppāl le /// %8 #Xx 3 /// (e)ṅkormeṃ kenīne lamästär-ne_(Prs.)|lamästär-ne auntsate-ne|autsate-ne rupaśke kantwas(a) skāwa(tsi) /// 4 /// śaula-preñcai s{oṃ}śka se wate appakke snai traṅko|träṅko ñake päst rinastä(r)-c (·)t· ṣp· /// 5 /// (we)ṣṣäṃ āppa ate yāmtsi päkn(ā)star-ñ || walo weṣṣäṃ larekka brāhmaṇeṃts|brāhmaṇets āyor aiskau-c || /// 6 /// ne weṣṣäṃ : saswa appakka (yakṣ)ī caimp skente mā brāhmaṇi päst ṅke śwāṃ-ñ_(Sub.Pl.)|śwā-ñ ce yolo – ///

1 /// [n](·) aṣkār[o] : lareṃnmeṃ t[s]relñ(·)s(·) saṃsārn(·) [_k_a]py· ce p(·)lyks(·)t(·) – /// 2 /// nmausa śānmyatai prākre twe _p_arkreṃ prekentsa : ña[k]e nai printsar ce uppāl le- /// 3 /// ○ ṅkormeṃ kenīne la_m_as_t_ar-ne autsate-ne rupaśke kantwas(·) skāw[a]- /// 4 /// ○ śaula-preñcai sauśka se wate appakke snai t_r_aṅko ñake _p_as_tä\ rinas_t_a(·)[c](·) t(·) ṣp(·) /// 5 /// _ṣ_ṣ_aṃ āppa ate yāmtsi _p_a[kn](·)s[ta]r-ñä\ || walo we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ larekka brāhmaṇet_s\ āyor aiskau-c\• || /// 6 /// [n]e we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ : saswa appakka (– ·)[ī] [c]aim_p\• skente mā brāhmaṇi _p_as_t\ ṅke śwā-ñä\ ce yolo – ///

3, 5. There is no trace of an anusvara on either autsate-ne (for auntsate) in line 3 or brāhmaṇets (for brāhmaṇeṃts) in line 5, so that Sieg/Siegling restore one in both cases; however, these are rather instances of genuine nasal loss in front of ts, which is a feauture of late and colloquial texts; see [[Peyrot 2008]]: 69.

4 The reading sauśka for soṃśka is certain; a similar form sauśke is found on the following leaf [[THT 84]] b 6. Even though the graphemes oṃ and au look quite similar, the two spellings are most likely not simply due to copyist errors but are rather hypercorrect spellings, since in the late/colloquial language the sequence oṃś turns to auś; see [[Peyrot 2008]]: 91-93.

The translation follows [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 312. In [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 21 the first two lines are interpreted as a soliloquy by the king, as a “Zwiegespräch mit dem eigenen Ich” (i.e. “dialogue with the inner self”; [[Thomas 1957]]: 185).

1. Sieg/Siegling propose to read and restore kä(r)py(eṃ) "common", cf. kärpye-saṃsār in [[IOL Toch 1]] b 4; but there is a trace of the vowel sign left that can only be ā, o, or au, cf. [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 312, fn. 56, who, nevertheless, accepts the correction to kä(r)py(eṃ). The middle Pt III form p(·)lyks(·)t(·) has to be restored to a zero-grade form p(a)lyks(a)t(ai); see [[Hackstein 1995]]: 111, fn. 6 with ref. At the end, Sieg/Siegling restored (twe no), [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 50, fn. 7 (twe ṣek).

1-2. The meter has 4 x 17 (6/6/5) syllables.

2. [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 50, fn. 8 also propose the word separation uppāll e, and even though words starting with le are rare (none fits here), such a gemination in sandhi is unusual. Sandhi gemination is usually found at morpheme boundaries, but, to my knowledge, not in compounds (the form may be one).

3. Note the tense alternation between present and preterite.

6. At the beginning, [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 51, fn. 3 propose to restore the m-Part. (miwama)ne "trembling". As for the restoration of the lacuna, Sieg/Siegling in [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 21, fn. 14 propose the nom.pl. yākṣi (as attested in [[THT 3]] a 1), reading two completely missing akṣaras. In contrast, [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 51, fn. 4 restore yakṣī based on [[THT 85]] a 3/4. Then Thomas in [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 238 withdraws this interpretation, arguing for yākṣi again. However, there is a trace of the vowel sign left, which can only belong to a long ī, not to a short one.
